case_name: Central Bank of India Limited v. Cashew Products Corporation Ltd., P.S. George and S. Chattanatha Karayalar

facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 405 of 1964 is an appeal by certificate brought on behalf of the 3rd defendant against the judgment and decree of the Kerala High Court dated July 18, 1962 in A.S. No. 561 of 1961.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE Jurisdiction Civil Appeal No. 405 of 1964. Appeal from the judgment and decree dated July 18, 1962 of the Kerala High Court in A.S. No. 561 of 1961. T. Desai, M.S.K. Sastri and M.S. Narasimhan for the appellant.

facts.text: The Kerala High Court judgment dated July 18, 1962 in A.S. No. 561 of 1961 affirmed the judgment and decree of the Subordinate Judge of Alleppey in O.S. No. 114 of 1957.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal from the judgment and decree dated July 18, 1962 of the Kerala High Court in A.S. No. 561 of 1961 which affirmed the judgment and decree of the Court of the Subordinate Judge of Alleppey in O.S. No. 114 of 1957.

facts.text: By resolution Ex. BD dated November 25, 1946, the Board of Directors of the 1st defendant Company authorised the 2nd defendant to obtain financial accommodation from the plaintiff-bank to the extent of Rs. 15 lakhs under different kinds of loans.

anchor.surface_text: By a resolution Ex. BD dated November 25, 1946 the Board of Directors of the 1st defendant Company authorised the 2nd defendant to obtain financial accommodation from the plaintiffbank to the extent of Rs. 15 lakhs under different kinds of loans.

facts.text: Company by its letter Ex. DE dated November 26, 1946 asked for accommodation for Rs. 1 lakh under clean overdraft, for Rs. 4 lakhs under open loan and for Rs. 10 lakhs under out agency and key loans.

anchor.surface_text: Pursuant to this resolution the Company by its letter Ex. DE dated November 26, 1946 asked for accommodation for Rs. 1 lakh under clean overdraft, for Rs. 4 lakhs under open loan and for Rs. 10 lakhs under out agency and key loans.

facts.text: On November 26, 1946 all the three defendants executed a promissory note Ex. B in favour of the plaintiff-bank for a sum of Rs. 4 lakhs.

anchor.surface_text: On November 26. 1946 all the three defendants executed a promissory numbere, Ex. B in favour of the plaintiff-bank for a sum of Rs. 4 lakhs. The promissory numbere was sent to the plaintiffs-bank along with a letter--Ex. A styled letter of companytinuity dated November 26, 1946.

facts.text: The promissory note Ex. B was sent to the plaintiff-bank along with letter Ex. A dated November 26, 1946 styled letter of continuity.

anchor.surface_text: The promissory numbere was sent to the plaintiffs-bank along with a letter--Ex. A styled letter of companytinuity dated November 26, 1946. Ex. A reads as follows Alleppey. 26th November, 1946.

facts.text: On the same day, defendant No. 1 as Borrower executed in favour of the plaintiff-bank Ex. G, a deed of hypothecation of its stocks of goods for securing the Demand Cash credit to the extent of Rs. 4 lakhs.

anchor.surface_text: On the same day, defendant No. 1 as Borrower executed in favour of the plaintiff-bank Ex. G, a deed of hypothecation of its stocks of goods for securing the Demand Cash credit. Ex. G is to the following effect Hypothecation of goods to secure a Demand cash Credit.

facts.text: On the basis of those documents the plaintiff-bank opened an overdraft account in the name of defendant No. 1.

anchor.surface_text: On the basis of those documents the plaintiff-bank opened an overdraft account in the name of defendant No. 1. On December 21, 1949, the three documents--Ex. A. B and G were renewed in identical terms by Exs. C, D and F.

facts.text: On December 21, 1949, the three documents Ex. A, B and G were renewed in identical terms by Exs. C, D and F.

anchor.surface_text: On December 21, 1949, the three documents--Ex. A. B and G were renewed in identical terms by Exs. C, D and F. On January I, 1950 a sum of Rs. 3,24,645/12/2 became due to the plaintiff-bank and on that date a demand numberice-Ex. 0 was sent by the plaintiff-bank for repayment of the amount.

facts.text: On January 1, 1950 a sum of Rs. 3,24,645/12/2 became due to the plaintiff-bank and on that date a demand notice Ex. O was sent by the plaintiff-bank for repayment.

anchor.surface_text: On January I, 1950 a sum of Rs. 3,24,645/12/2 became due to the plaintiff-bank and on that date a demand numberice-Ex. 0 was sent by the plaintiff-bank for repayment of the amount. A second numberice---Ex. L was sent by the plaintiff-bank on April 26, 1950.

facts.text: A second notice Ex. L was sent by the plaintiff-bank on April 26, 1950.

anchor.surface_text: A second numberice---Ex. L was sent by the plaintiff-bank on April 26, 1950. On September 8. 1950 the plaintiffbank brought a suit for the recovery of Rs. 2,86,292/11/11 from all the three defendants.

facts.text: On September 8, 1950 the plaintiff-bank brought a suit O.S. No. 114 of 1957 for the recovery of Rs. 2,86,292/11/11 from all the three defendants.

anchor.surface_text: On September 8. 1950 the plaintiffbank brought a suit for the recovery of Rs. 2,86,292/11/11 from all the three defendants. The suit was companytested by all the defendants.

facts.text: The suit was contested by all the defendants.

anchor.surface_text: The suit was companytested by all the defendants. The case of defendant No. 1 was that it had sustained loss on account of sudden termination of credit facilities by the plaintiff-bank and the amount of loss sustained should be set off against the claim of the plaintiff-bank.

facts.text: Defendant No. 1 claimed it had sustained loss on account of sudden termination of credit facilities by the plaintiff-bank and the amount of loss should be set off against the claim.

anchor.surface_text: The case of defendant No. 1 was that it had sustained loss on account of sudden termination of credit facilities by the plaintiff-bank and the amount of loss sustained should be set off against the claim of the plaintiff-bank.

facts.text: Defendants Nos. 2 and 3 pleaded that they had executed the promissory notes only as a surety for the 1st defendant.

anchor.surface_text: Defendants Nos. 2 and 3 pleaded that they had executed the promissory numberes only as a surety for the 1st defendant and that they are number companyobligants.

facts.text: Defendants alleged that the plaintiff-bank had made adjustments in the open loan account and in the clean overdraft account by debiting and correspondingly crediting in other accounts without the consent of defendants 2 and 3.

anchor.surface_text: It was said that the plaintiff-bank had made adjustments in the open loan account and in the clean over-draft account by debiting and companyrespondingly crediting in other accounts without the companysent of defendants 2 and 3.

facts.text: Defendants alleged that the plaintiff-bank had allowed defendant No. 1 to over-draw freely in the clean overdraft and open loan accounts far beyond the limits agreed upon.

anchor.surface_text: The plaintiff- bank had also allowed defendant No. 1 to over-draw freely in the clean overdraft and open loan accounts far beyond the limits agreed upon.

facts.text: Defendants contended that the plaintiff-bank had converted secured loans into simple loans by releasing goods covered by Bills of Lading against trust receipts and had thereby frittered away such securities.

anchor.surface_text: It was alleged that the plaintiff-bank had companyverted secured loans into simple loans by releasing goods companyered by Bills of Lading against trust receipts and had thereby deliberately frittered away such securities.

facts.text: The Subordinate Judge of Alleppey held that defendants 2 and 3 were co-obligants, not merely sureties, because they executed the promissory notes Exs. B D.

anchor.surface_text: Upon these rival companytentions the learned Subordinate Judge of Alleppey took the view that defendants 2 and 3 were number merely sureties but they were companyobligants, because they had executed the promissory numberes--Exs. B D.

facts.text: Defendant No. 3 presented an appeal in the Kerala High Court in A.S. 561 of 1961, which was dismissed on July 12, 1962, affirmed by supplementary judgment on July 18, 1962.

anchor.surface_text: Against the judgment and decree of learned Subordinate Judge, Alleppey defendant No. 3 presented an appeal in the High Court of Kerala under A.S. 561 of 1961. ... The appeal was dismissed by the High Court of Kerala on July 12, 1962.

facts.text: The Supreme Court held that the 3rd defendant is a surety and not a co-obligant with regard to the overdraft account transaction.

anchor.surface_text: Our companycluded opinion, therefore, is that the status of the 3rd defendant with regard to the overdraft account was that of a surety and number companyobligant and the finding of the High Court on this issue is number companyrect.

facts.text: The case is remanded to the Kerala High Court for deciding whether defendant No. 3 is discharged of his liability as a surety due to the conduct of the plaintiff-bank.

anchor.surface_text: We companysider it necessary that this case should go back on remand to the High Court of Kerala for deciding the issue and to give proper relief to the parties.

facts.text: On July 16, 1962 defendant No. 3 filed C.M.P. No. 5032 of 1962 in High Court praying that arguments on his liability be expressly dealt with.

anchor.surface_text: On July 16, 1962 defendant No. 3 filed C.M.P. No. 5032 of 1962 praying that the argument of the appellant with regard to his liability as companyobligant may be expressly dealt with in the judgment of the High Court.

concepts.interpretation: Documents Exs. A, B and G executed contemporaneously between the parties on November 26, 1946 form one integrated transaction and must be read together to ascertain the status of the 3rd defendant as surety.

interpretation_anchor.surface_text: d number equally of both, so that the other if he should be companypelled to pay it, would be entitled to reimbursement from the persons by whom  as b

concepts.unlisted_label: Doctrine of Reading Contemporaneous Documents of Same Transaction Together
concepts.unlisted_description: Several documents forming part of one transaction and executed contemporaneously are to be construed as one document.

concepts.interpretation: Section 126 requires the creditor to be a party to the contract of guarantee; satisfied here as plaintiff-bank was party to Ex. A (letter of continuity) and Ex. G (hypothecation), contemporaneous with Ex. B.
concepts.unlisted_description: Definition of contract of guarantee, surety, principal debtor, and creditor.
Surety's right to benefit of creditor's securities.

concepts.interpretation: Creditor not bound by private contract between co-debtors; but inapplicable here as bank was party to the guarantee contract in Ex. A.
concepts.unlisted_description: Creditor's liability regarding contracts between co-debtors.

concepts.interpretation: Does not bar evidence of collateral written agreements (Exs. A and G) that form part of the same transaction as the promissory note (Ex. B).
concepts.unlisted_description: Exclusion of oral evidence to contradict or vary terms of document.

concepts.interpretation: Remanded to High Court to decide if surety discharged due to bank's adjustments in accounts without consent, overdrawing beyond limits, conversion of secured to unsecured loans by releasing securities.
concepts.unlisted_description: Surety discharged by creditor's prejudicial conduct, variance in contract, or impairment of securities.

issues.text: whether the status of the 3rd defendant in regard to the transaction of overdraft account is that of a surety or of a co-obligant

anchor.surface_text: The first question presented for determination in this case is whether the status of the 3rd defendant in regard to the transaction of overdraft account is that of a surety or of a co-obligant.

issues.text: whether defendant No. 3 is discharged of his liability as a surety by reason of the alleged conduct of the plaintiff-bank in violating the terms of the agreement--Ex. G or by the alleged fraudulent or negligent conduct of the plaintiff-bank in other ways
whether there is a contract of suretyship in the present case in terms of s. 126 of the Contract Act
whether the provisions of s. 92 of the Evidence Act apply in the present case to bar evidence of collateral agreements Exs. A and G
whether the creditor is bound by any contract between the co-debtors under s. 132 of the Contract Act
whether the suit is based on the promissory note Ex. B or upon the balance of the overdraft account

arguments.claim: The High Court misconstrued Exs. A and B; there was an integrated transaction by Exs. A, B and G making 3rd defendant a surety not co-obligant

anchor.surface_text: It was argued by Mr. Desai on behalf of the appellant that the High Court has misconstrued the contents of Exs. A and B in holding that the 3rd defendant has undertaken the liability as a co-obligant. It was submitted that there was an integrated transaction constituted by the various documents---Exs. A, B and G executed between the parties on the same day and the legal effect of the documents was to confer on the 3rd defendant the status of a surety and not of a co-obligant.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: refore, number applicable and Mr. Pathak is number able to make good his submission on this aspect of the case.  1  1881 6 A.C.I. A.I.R. 1935 Mad. 643

arguments.court_reasoning: Documents form one transaction per established principle; language shows PN as security for OD; bank letters treat as guarantor

arguments.claim: Status of 3rd defendant is surety not co-obligant as per integrated reading of Exs. A, B, G

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, the argument put forward on behalf of the appellant is well-founded and must be accepted as correct. It is true that in the promissory note--Ex. B all the three defendants have jointly and severally promised to pay...

arguments.claim: No contract of suretyship per s.126 Contract Act; bank not bound to treat 3rd def as surety

anchor.surface_text: On behalf of respondent No. 1 Mr. Pathak stressed the argument that there is no contract of suretyship in the present case in terms of s. 126 of the Contract Act and the plaintiff-bank is not, legally bound to treat the 3rd defendant merely in the character of a surety.

arguments.court_reasoning: Legal proposition correct but inapplicable; bank was party to Ex. A (guarantee) and Ex. G contemporaneous with Ex. B, satisfying s.126

arguments.claim: Under s.132 Contract Act, creditor not bound by contract between co-debtors even if aware
arguments.court_reasoning: Inapplicable as bank was party to the guarantee contract Ex. A, not a private contract between co-debtors

arguments.claim: s.92 Evidence Act bars evidence of collateral transaction; 3rd def is co-obligant per PN terms
arguments.court_reasoning: s.92 does not apply; not oral evidence derogating PN but contemporaneous written docs Exs. A,G part of same transaction

arguments.claim: Suit based on promissory note Ex. B not on overdraft account balance
arguments.court_reasoning: Plaint based on OD balance per para 11, notices refer to accounts not PN; respondent's own statement confirms OD basis

arguments.claim: 3rd defendant is co-obligant and not surety per High Court

anchor.surface_text: The appeal was dismissed by the High Court of Kerala on July 12, 1962. It was held by the High Court that defendant No. 3 was a co-obligant and not a surety.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: refore, number applicable and Mr. Pathak is number able to make good his submission on this aspect of the case.  1  1881 6 A.C.I. A.I.R. 1935 Mad. 643

holdings.text: Our concluded opinion, therefore, is that the status of the 3rd defendant with regard to the overdraft account was that of a surety and not co-obligant and the finding of the High Court on this issue is not correct.

anchor.surface_text: Our concluded opinion, therefore, is that the status of the 3rd defendant with regard to the overdraft account was that of a surety and not co-obligant and the finding of the High Court on this issue is not correct.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Contemporaneous documents Exs. A, B and G constitute one integrated transaction; promissory note Ex. B given as security for overdraft per Ex. A; hypothecation Ex. G for cash credit account; bank's letters treat 3rd defendant as guarantor.

holdings.text: It is manifest, therefore, in the present case that the requirements of s. 126 of the Contract Act are satisfied and defendant No. 3 has the status of a surety and not of a co-obligant in the transaction of overdraft account opened in the name of defendant No. 1 by the plaintiff-bank.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Plaintiff-bank was party to contract of guarantee Ex. A contemporaneous with promissory note Ex. B and to hypothecation Ex. G.

holdings.text: The provisions of s. 92 of the Evidence Act do not apply in the present case, because defendant No. 3 is not attempting to furnish evidence of any oral agreement in derogation of the promissory note but relying on the existence of a collateral agreement in writing--Exs. A G which form parts of the same transaction as the promissory note--Ex. B.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Defendant No. 3 relies on contemporaneous written collateral agreements Exs. A and G forming part of same transaction as Ex. B, not oral evidence derogating the promissory note.

holdings.text: We consider that the legal proposition for which Mr. Pathak is contending is correct, but the argument has no much relevance in the present case. It is true that s. 126 of the Contract Act requires that the creditor must be a party to the contract of guarantee. It is also true that under s. 132 of the Contract Act the creditor is not bound by any contract between the co-debtors that one of them shall be liable only on the default of the other even though the creditor may have been aware of the existence of the contract between the two co-debtors.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Legal proposition under s.132 correct that creditor not bound by private contract between co-debtors, but inapplicable as bank was party to guarantee Ex. A.

holdings.text: We are satisfied, on examination of the language of the plaint, that the suit is based not upon the promissory note but upon the balance of the overdraft account in the books of the plaintiff-bank.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Plaint para 11 seeks recovery as per accounts annexed; notices Exs. O and L refer to accounts not promissory note; respondent's own case statement confirms overdraft basis.

holdings.text: The principle is well-established that if the transaction is contained in more than one document between the same parties they must be read and interpreted together and they have the same legal effect for all purposes as if they are one document.

anchor.surface_text: The principle is well-established that if the transaction is contained in more than one document between the same parties they must be read and interpreted together and they have the same legal effect for all purposes as if they are one document.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Applied to Exs. A, B, G executed contemporaneously on same day between same parties; cited Manks v. Whiteley.

anchor.surface_text: In Manks v. Whiteley, 1  Moulton, L.J. stated Where several deeds form part of one transaction and are contemporaneously executed they have the same effect for all purposes such as are relevant to this case as if they were one deed. Each is executed on the faith of all the others being executed also and is intended to speak only as part of the one transaction, and if one is seeking to make equities apply to the parties they must be equities arising out of the transaction as a whole.

precedents.cited_proposition: Several deeds which form part of one transaction and are contemporaneously executed have the same effect for all purposes as if they were one deed
precedents.cited_holding: Where several deeds form part of one transaction and are contemporaneously executed they have the same effect for all purposes such as are relevant to this case as if they were one deed.

precedents.citation: Vyravan Chettiar v. Official Assignee of Madras 1

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Pathak relied upon the decision of the Madras High Court in Vyravan Chettiar v. Official Assignee of Madras 1  in which it is pointed out that persons who are jointly and severally liable on promissory notes are not sureties under s. 126 of the Contract Act, nor do such persons occupy a position analogous to that of a surety strictly so called to attract the provisions of s. 141 of the Contract Act.

precedents.case_name: Vyravan Chettiar v Official Assignee of Madras
precedents.cited_proposition: Persons jointly and severally liable on promissory notes are not sureties under s. 126 Contract Act nor analogous to surety for s. 141

precedents.citation: Duncan Fox Co. v. North South Wales Bank 2

anchor.surface_text: Reference was made, in this connection, to the decision of the House of Lords in Duncan Fox Co. v. North South Wales Bank 2  in which Lord Selbourne, L.C. distinguished between three kinds of cases  1  those in which there is an agreement to constitute, for a particular purpose, the relation of principal and surety, to which agreement the creditor thereby secured is a party  2  those in which there is a similar agreement between the principal and surety only, to which the creditor, is a stranger, and  3  those in which, without any such contract of suretyship, there is a primary and a secondary liability of two persons for one and the same debt

precedents.case_name: Duncan Fox Co v North and South Wales Bank
precedents.cited_proposition: Distinction between three classes of suretyship cases; even in non-strict suretyship cases, the payer is entitled to subrogation to creditor's securities
precedents.cited_holding: In all these kinds of cases the person who discharged the liability due to the creditor, would be entitled to the benefit of the security held by the creditor though a case of suretyship strictly speaking would fall only under class 1

anchor.surface_text: On behalf of respondent No. 1 Mr. Pathak also referred to the decision in Venkata Krishnayya v. Karnedan Kothari 2  and submitted that defendant No. 3 cannot be permitted to give evidence in regard to a collateral transaction in view of the bar imposed by s. 92 of the Evidence Act and his position is as a co-obligant and that the terms of the promissory note cannot be altered by any other transaction.

precedents.cited_proposition: Evidence of collateral transaction barred by s.92 Evidence Act to vary terms of promissory note

anchor.surface_text: Our concluded opinion, therefore, is that the status of the 3rd defendant with regard to the overdraft account was that of a surety and not co-obligant and the finding of the High Court on this issue is not correct.
For these reasons we allow this appeal, set aside the judgment and decree of the High Court of Kerala dated July 18, 1962 in A.S. 561 of 1961 and ord
